awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Interrogating the Free Troposphere during the Last Deglaciation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to provide the first global-scale constraints on temperature and dynamics of the free- troposphere- which comprises altitudes ranging from about 2 - 18 km. Specifically, the researcher will use new isotopic measurements and 3 Dimensional (3D) global modeling to reconstruct and interpret high-altitude atmospheric temperature and circulation changes during the last deglaciation (18,000 to 8,000 years before present). This project will use an emerging tracer from ice-core records to generate a paleo-temperature record that will reveal the state of the troposphere and its interaction with the stratosphere across the most recent major climate transition in Earth history. Research goals include constraining the thermal evolution of the free troposphere during a time period that includes several episodes of abrupt climate change; testing modeled free-troposphere responses to orbital and greenhouse-gas forcing; and testing stratosphere-to- troposphere exchange dynamics across major climate transitions. This combined measurement-modeling study will constrain the paleoclimate at altitude during the most recent major episode of global change, when circulation patterns shifted under different climatic boundary conditions. 

The potential Broader Impacts include developing a new temperature record of the free troposphere during the last deglaciation. The application of a new isotopic tracer to investigate the dynamics of stratosphere-troposphere exchange is potentially transformative for paleoclimate research. Other broader impacts include participation of the researchers in STEM outreach events as part of their ongoing activities, including participation in the department’s annual Earth Day at Rice University with the Girl Scouts. The project will train one undergraduate and two graduate students, and support two early career researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: This project has deepened our understanding of Earth's atmospheric changes during key periods of its recent history. The project first measured ice-core samples from Antarctica and Greenland for their oxygen isotope anomalies. The project then embedded this isotope chemistry online within a global atmospheric model that can simulate atmospheric chemistry at different points during the last few Ice Age cycles. By comparing the measurements with the model, we were able to estimate, for the first time, temperature changes at high altitudes since the peak of the last Ice Age, 21,000 years ago. This project found a 6–9°C cooling compared to the recent past, aligning with climate model predictions and helping to better understand this crucial natural feedback in the climate system. A separate research study associated with the project also revealed lower-atmospheric ozone to be 9 % lower during the Last Interglacial period, 127,000 years ago, which is otherwise the most similar climate analogue to our climate just before the start of the Industrial Revolution. By comparing the ice-core observations over this longer period with global atmospheric modeling, the project concluded that the difference in ozone is most likely due to changing amounts of wildfires that would have occurred after the extinction of large animals, as these large animals influence the distribution of forests. The findings of this project improve the accuracy of climate models and our knowledge of historical atmospheric conditions and the factors that influence them.

 

Broader Impacts: The project trained two graduate students and one postdoctoral fellow in a unique collaborative team between two universities that worked across typical measurement-modeling barriers, demonstrating the utility of interdisciplinary research in informing both science and policy. The historical context and insights into the atmosphere offered by this project over studies of the modern atmosphere provided a valuable and presently missing perspective from which to evaluate the impacts of strategies proposed for climate-change adaptation. The project’s findings on historical temperature changes and ozone levels shed light on natural climate feedback mechanisms and the role of ecological shifts, such as the extinction of large animals, in shaping atmospheric conditions. These insights can guide current conservation efforts, emphasizing the strong connections between ecosystems and climate. Lastly, the model tools developed for this project are now being publicly served for use by the general scientific community, allowing research groups around the world to study interactions between atmospheric chemistry and climate change.
